raw_text:
Help for indies in download sales
 
 A campaign has been launched to help independent labels get their music online and benefit from the growing trend for downloading music.
 
 The British Phonographic Industry has identified a lack of independent music available for download. "We want to ensure that independent repertoire is as successful in the download world as it is in the physical world," said BPI chief Peter Jamieson. Downloaded singles have now overtaken physical singles in the UK. Mr Jamieson said his organisation was lobbying music service providers, which include iTunes and Napster, to urge them to promote independent releases. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year. "With downloads shortly to be eligible for the singles chart, this is a key commercial issue on which the BPI committed to assisting its members," added Mr Jamieson. As part of the campaign the BPI is running a series of seminars entitled Getting Your Music Online, focusing on how independent labels can embrace digital music. The US has already begun incorporating download sales in the Billboard's Hot 100 chart.
llama3.2:1b: A campaign aims to help independent labels get their music online and benefit from downloading trends, with the British Phonographic Industry lobbying service providers for promotional support.
llama3.2:3b: The British Phonographic Industry has launched a campaign to help independent labels promote their music online for download, with a goal of ensuring equal success for indie repertoire as physical releases. The BPI is lobbying music service providers and running seminars on getting music online to assist its members, ahead of download sales becoming eligible for the UK singles chart later this year.
gemma2:2b: The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) launched a campaign to help independent labels sell their music online through downloads.  They want to ensure success in this market by promoting independent releases and working with music service providers to make it happen. The BPI will incorporate download sales into the UK singles chart later this year and is running seminars on how to leverage digital music for independent labels.

It aims to ensure that independent artists' albums become as successful as physical music in digital downloads, with Downloads currently ranking ahead of physical singles in the UK market. The campaign includes seminars focusing on how indie labels can use digital platforms.
qwen2.5:1.5b: A campaign aims to help indie labels get their music online and benefit from downloads, following BPI's lobbying of music service providers like iTunes and Napster for increased promotion of independent releases. Download sales are set to be included in the UK singles chart this year as part of a series of seminars on online distribution organized by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI).
qwen2.5:3b: A campaign by the British Phonographic Industry aims to help independent labels gain online presence and benefit from growing download trends. They identified a lack of independent music for downloads, with downloaded singles now overtaking physical singles in UK. The BPI is lobbying music service providers like iTunes and Napster to promote independent releases. Download sales are set to be included in the UK singles chart later this year. To assist members, the BPI runs seminars focusing on how independent labels can engage with digital music. US has already incorporated download sales into Billboard's Hot 100 chart.

Help for indies in download sales

A campaign has been launched to help independent labels get their music online and benefit from the growing trend for downloading music. British Phonographic Industry has identified a lack of independent music available for download, "We want to ensure that independent repertoire is as successful in the download world as it is in the physical world," said BPI chief Peter Jamieson. Downloaded singles have now overtaken physical singles in the UK, Mr Jamieson said his organisation was lobbying music service providers, which include iTunes and Napster, to urge them to promote independent releases. smollm:1.7b:
Independent labels have launched a campaign to help their music reach online listeners and benefit from the growing trend for downloading music. The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) has identified a lack of independent music available for download, which is why it is launching this campaign. Independent labels are encouraged by BPI to promote their music on digital platforms, such as iTunes and Napster, in order to increase their online sales. This will help indie labels get more exposure and reach a wider audience. The UK singles chart has already been affected by the growing trend for downloading music, which is why the BPI is urging its members to promote their music on digital platforms.

The campaign aims to educate independent labels about how they can effectively use digital platforms to reach online listeners and increase their sales. This includes providing guidance on how to create a strong online presence, including creating an online store and promoting their music through social media. The BPI is also running seminars that focus on the benefits of using digital platforms for indie labels, which will help them get more exposure and reach a wider audience.

The campaign is expected to be successful in increasing the number of independent labels available for download and ultimately boost sales. With downloads becoming an increasingly important part of the music industry, this campaign aims to give indie labels a competitive edge in the online market.

The main points seem to be: A campaign is launched by indie labels to get music online and support the trend of downloading. The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) has identified a lack of independent music in downloads. They mention that downloaded singles are now leading physical ones in the UK, which suggests an opportunity for indie artists.

Mr. Jamieson from BPI is involved in lobbying with music providers like iTunes and Napster to push them promote indie releases. Download sales are set to be part of the singles chart in the UK later this year. There's also mention of a series of seminars running by BPI aimed at helping indie labels get their music online.

The US has already started incorporating downloads into Billboard's Hot 100, which indicates that similar efforts might be expanding there as well. The overall goal seems to be to address the growing trend towards digital music and provide easier access for independent artists to reach a broader audience.

I'll focus on the main campaign, the BPI's role, the shift in downloads, Mr. Jamieson's efforts with songwriters, the incorporation of downloads into singles chart, and the partial success in the US.

I should also mention that this is an ongoing initiative to help indie labels gain more visibility both domestically and internationally through digital platforms.
</think>

A campaign has been launched by indie labels to help independent music artists access their music online and support the growing trend for downloading. The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) identified a lack of independent music available in downloads, noting that downloaded singles have overtaken physical singles in the UK. Mr. Peter Jamieson, BPI's chief, mentioned lobbying with songwriters to encourage indie releases on platforms like iTunes and Napster. Download sales are expected to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year as downloaded music becomes eligible for charting. Meanwhile, download sales are already being implemented in the US, including Billboard's Hot 100 chart, which has begun incorporating downloads from independent labels.
tinyllama:1.1b: The British Phoenographic Industry has launched a campaign to help independent labels benefit from the growing trend of downloading music and ensure that their releases are equally represented on download charts. The organization is lobbying service providers such as iTunes and Napster to promote independent music releases in addition to physical singles, which have already overtaken sales in the UK. The BPI is also running a series of semi-narratives entitled "Getting Your Music Online" to guide indie labels in embracing digital distribution. The campaign highlights download sales' inclusion in the Billboard Hot 100 chart as an important commercial issue that needs assistance from industry organizations.
tinydolphin:1.1b: As the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) and major music service providers continue to explore methods of promoting and enabling the growth of independent repertoire, a campaign has been launched to facilitate such efforts for indie labels in particular. This initiative seeks to ensure that indie artists can capitalize on the growing demand for downloading digital singles as they continue to dominate the music charts. In order to address this issue, the BPI is working closely with industry partners such as iTunes and Napster to promote independent releases in a way that resonates with consumers. The campaign also aims to incorporate download sales into the UK singles chart later this year, thereby providing indie labels more opportunities to leverage their music repertoire within this increasingly important marketplace.

granite3.1-dense:2b: The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) is launching a campaign to aid independent music labels in making their music accessible for online downloading, addressing the growing trend of digital music consumption. BPI Chief Peter Jamieson emphasizes the need to match the success of independent tracks in downloads as they already dominate physical singles sales in the UK. The organization is lobbying major download platforms like iTunes and Napster to promote independent releases, with download sales expected to be included in the UK singles chart by later this year. As part of this initiative, BPI is organizing seminars titled "Getting Your Music Online" to guide independent labels on embracing digital music distribution. This move follows the US practice of including download sales in its Hot 100 chart.
